awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Responses of Desert Endotherms to Rapid Recent Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Considerable uncertainty exists about the effects of changing climates on the distributions of plants and animals. Most studies of recent climate change on species' geographic ranges are based on projections from computer models rather than measured responses from field studies. This research takes a very different and multi-tiered approach by using historical records and specimens with the necessary precision, geographic and temporal scale, and magnitude of observed climate change to produce important insights into the direct and indirect effects of climatic and nonclimatic factors on changes in species' geographic distributions. This research will resurvey field sites in the southwest United States last surveyed more than 70 years ago, which will not only advance our understanding of environmental changes but will establish a new benchmark for comparison of future changes. Federal land-management agencies will benefit from greater knowledge of the status of sensitive species and wildlife responses to climate change. Specimens and audio recordings collected will be available for ancillary studies. Results will be extended broadly to the public through talks, popular press and media, and museum displays, including new exhibits of the San Diego Natural History Museum and the Oakland Museum of California. The National Park Service Science and Education Office will distribute results widely through videos and podcasts to train their interpreters on the biological effects of environmental change and to provide interpretive materials for their visitor centers. Undergraduates, graduate student and postdoctoral researchers will participate in this study, learning field and lab techniques, natural history, physiological methods and modeling. Results and data will be shared with scientists and the general public through websites and online databases. 

This project will resurvey sites that were sampled from 1908-1945 to examine the impact of 20th century climate change on small mammal and bird communities in Sonoran, Mojave, and Great Basin deserts. These areas have warmed greatly over the last 50 years, with the average annual temperatures increasing up to 2°C. The research will advance understanding of animal responses to climate change by: developing new models that mechanistically project species' ranges by linking climate through important physiological thresholds of temperature and water stress; developing novel tests to examine whether climate change results in species shifting their geographic ranges individually or whether whole communities of species shift similarly; and testing if body sizes and diets of species have responded to climate change. Birds and mammals will be resurveyed at 105 sites. Both audio and physical voucher specimens will be collected and made available for future reanalysis. Standard morphological data will be collected for birds and mammal skulls. Ratios of carbon and nitrogen isotopes will be measured from tissues. Multispecies occupancy models will account for detectability in historical and current surveys to develop unbiased estimators of local colonization and extinction of species and changes in community composition in response to site-level characteristics. Measures of thermal and hydric stress at and above the upper limit of the thermal neutral zone will be made for 12 species of mammals to develop models of heat stress that can be validated.

por.por_cntn:
This research was a collaboration between the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology (MVZ) at UC Berkeley, San Diego Natural History Museum (SDNHM), UC Santa Cruz, Univ. of New Mexico and the National Park Service to resurvey birds and small mammals at 106 sites originally surveyed prior to significant climate warming (1908-1945) by MVZ professor Joseph Grinnell and colleagues in and adjacent to Death Valley National Park, Mojave National Preserve, and Joshua Tree National Park. Sites in these national parks are protected from land-use change but not from climate change. The Mojave Desert is a hotspot of climate change, having warmed and dried more than most other regions in North America, so species will need to adapt, move far and fast, or die in response to climate change. UC Berkeley was the lead institution, and coordinated the resurvey efforts and their integrated analysis.

Our resurveys discovered that a massive decline in the occurrence of bird species took place over the last century in the Mojave Desert as a result of climate change. When we revisit a site that was surveyed a century ago, we find about half as many bird species as the original surveyors did, even after we account for differences in detecting species. Of 135 bird species that were detected, 39 (29%) declined in the proportion of sites that they now occur, while only one species (the Common Raven) increased over the past century. Climate change and in particular the long-term decline in precipitation was the strongest predictor of the collapse of the bird community rather than fire, grazing, or recent weather.

In sharp comparison to the birds, the occupancy of Mojave sites by small mammals remained stable over the last century. The mean percent of sites occupied by small mammals during the original surveys in the early 1900’s was indistinguishable from the modern surveys (both 26%). Moreover, there was little change in the number of mammal species per site. Sites supported an average of 8.79 mammal species in the historic surveys compared to 8.92 species in the modern surveys. However, the stability of mammal species richness conceals moderate species turnover at survey sites. There was an average gain of 2.02 mammal species colonizing per site (23%) and an average loss of 1.89 species per site (22%). 

A major objective for our research was to understand how the physiological requirements of birds and mammals influenced their changes in occupancy in the Mojave Desert over the last century. To do this, we developed biophysical models to predict the amount of heat that a bird or mammal would need to gain or lose in order to maintain a stable body temperature, which is a fundamental requirement for survival. The model linked species traits, such as body size, shape, and insulation properties of their feathers and fur, to climate and its changes.

We used this model to quantify the heating and cooling requirements in 50 species of Mojave birds and found an increase in cooling costs over the past century was a likely mechanism underlying bird declines. On average, cooling costs for birds are now 18.8% higher compared to historic climates. Cooling costs increased the most for bigger birds, with the largest species experiencing a 42-fold increase in cooling costs relative the smallest species for the same degree of warming. Mojave bird species that declined the most had the greatest increases in cooling costs.

Despite widespread warming at the Mojave resurvey sites, we found that exposure to climate change differed dramatically between the bird and small mammal communities. This affected the amount of water required for evaporative cooling to maintain homeothermy (which we called “cooling costs”), a critical aspect of survival that was quantified by our models. Cooling costs were 3.3-times higher in birds relative to mammals across a landscape representative of climatic extremes in the Mojave Desert. Climate change caused the costs to increase by 58.5% for birds but only 17.4% for small mammals. Overall, birds experienced higher cooling costs at survey sites than mammals. In fact, over 80% of small mammals experienced low to no change in cooling costs from climate change over the past century because they spend the hottest periods of the day in their underground burrows where it is much cooler.

Taken as a whole, our research provides some of the strongest evidence yet for the direct effect of climate change on the distribution of organisms. Our work has brought to the attention of the US National Park Service a hitherto unnoticed change in the desert ecosystems they are entrusted to protect. This information was communicated to park managers and biologists through two webinars hosted by the National Park Service, and written reports to managers and scientists at each national park unit visited.
